title: 105_s2355
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truancy Prevention and Juvenile Crime Reduction Act of 1998". Congress finds that truancy is a significant issue, often leading to school dropouts and increased likelihood of welfare dependence, unemployment, and criminal behavior. High rates of truancy are associated with daytime burglary and vandalism, with a significant portion of violent juvenile crime occurring during school hours. High rates of truancy are linked to high daytime burglary and vandalism rates. Up to 44 percent of violent juvenile crime occurs during school hours, with as many as 75 percent of arrested children aged 13-16 being truants. Some cities report unexcused absences as high as 70 percent, totaling up to 4,000 absences per day. The social and economic costs of truancy are significant, with only 34 percent of inmates completing high school education and a high percentage of youth entering adult prisons without completing grade school. (8) Society faces significant social and economic costs due to truancy, with a low percentage of inmates completing high school education. Truants and high school dropouts cost the Nation $240 billion in lost earnings and foregone taxes. Effective truancy prevention programs can improve school attendance and reduce crime rates, but there is a lack of targeted funding for these programs in current law. SEC. 3. GRANTS. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "eligible partnership," "local educational agency," and "qualified unit of local government." The eligible partnership is described as a partnership between local government units and local educational agencies. The local educational agency is defined according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. A qualified unit of local government is a local government unit that meets specific requirements under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Act. The government must have a statute or regulation that meets specific requirements under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act to be eligible for a grant. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will award grants to eligible partnerships to reduce truancy and daytime juvenile crime on a competitive basis. The term "unit of local government" refers to various political subdivisions of a State or Indian tribe. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will award grants on a competitive basis to eligible partnerships to reduce truancy and daytime juvenile crime. Grants awarded under this section shall not exceed $100,000 in any fiscal year, with at least 25 percent allocated for use by the local educational agency. Grants may be renewed for up to 2 additional fiscal years. The grant awarded to eligible partnerships can be used by local educational agencies to address truancy. Grants can be renewed for up to 2 additional fiscal years. Funds can be used for parental involvement, sanctions for habitually truant students, and parental accountability. The curr_chunk discusses various strategies to address truancy, such as incentives for parental responsibility, sanctions for habitually truant students, parental accountability measures, in-school prevention programs, involvement of various community stakeholders, technology utilization, and eliminating the 40-day count. The curr_chunk discusses model programs for addressing truancy, including the Truancy Intervention Project in Fulton County, Georgia, the TABS program in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and the Roswell Daytime Curfew Program in Roswell. The curr_chunk lists model programs for addressing truancy, including initiatives in California, Connecticut, New Jersey, Oklahoma, and Virginia. The curr_chunk lists model programs for addressing truancy in various states, including Connecticut, New Jersey, Oklahoma, Virginia, Ohio, California, and New Mexico. The Attorney General may also determine other appropriate model programs. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for these programs. The Grade Court program in Farmington, New Mexico, and other model programs deemed appropriate by the Attorney General are listed as examples for addressing truancy. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for these programs.
